Sec. 2-233. - Procedure. (a) In the event a decision of any department of the county is appealed to the board of commissioners for review, the administrative procedures set out in these procedures shall provide guidance on how such an appeal shall be conducted. (b) To the extent that the documentation of the department from which the appeal arises has specific guidance for the filing and conduct of an appeal, those instructions will be followed unless otherwise specifically provided. In any case where the time provided for in the specific guidance is greater or lesser than the time provided herein, the greater time will prevail. (c) In the absence of a specific provision, the following shall control: (1) All appeals shall be filed initially with the department which issued the decision from which the appeal is taken. a. No appeal shall be accepted except an appeal in writing, signed by the person or entity appealing (the appellant). 1. An appeal by other than a natural person (corporation, limited liability company, etc.) must be signed by an officer or other person authorized to represent the entity. 2. An entity without legal status (for example, an informal business or an individual "doing business as" a "business name") must be filed in the name of the individual. 3. No other person may sign for a person or entity filing an appeal unless the person signing is duly authorized in writing to represent the person or entity during the appeal. Any, each and every act by such authorized person shall be binding on the person or entity represented. If, in the sole discretion of the county manager it is determined that the agent or representative should be a designated "attorney in fact" acting under a written power of attorney, the county manager shall provide an appropriate form, the proper execution of which shall become a necessary part of the appeal. b. No appeal shall be accepted unless all fees due and payable have been paid. c. Each appeal shall be filed in ten copies, with each copy a compete set of all documents and exhibits to be considered. Any written statement or other document shall also be filed in ten copies. Any appeal which does not provide ten copies of each document, and each exhibit, photographs, books or other attachment, shall be refused. Any material added to the appeal after filing must also be provided in ten copies as set out below. No material shall be permitted to be entered during the appeal unless the specified copies have been provided in advance as required. (2) Within ten days following the date when the complete appeal has been filed, with all documents and exhibits in proper numbers of copies, the appeal shall be sent to the county manager for review. The department shall include with the appeal all background information, exhibits, and the decision of the department in ten copies. (3) Within ten days of receiving an appeal, the county manager shall either return the appeal to the department if any element of the appeal is not provided as set out in these procedures, or forward the appeal to the members of the board of commissioners for consideration. The county manager shall at that time poll the board members to determine a time and date certain at which the appeal shall be heard. (4) Within five days of providing the appeal to the members of the board, the county manager will set the time and date of the appeal, and will give notice to the department, the appellant, all members of the board of commissioners, and such additional parties at the county manager deems appropriate. (5) Appeals shall be set normally on a date and at a time not in conflict with other county business, and shall be the sole activity on the agenda; multiple appeals may be scheduled consecutively if required. a. Appeals, which have been set for a date and time, may be reset at the sole discretion of the county manager if required by the exigencies of the governing authority. b. An appellant may request in writing, stating the basis for the request, that a scheduled appeal be reset. Granting such request shall be in the sole discretion of the county manager, and shall only be granted for good cause shown. (6) An appeal may be amended or supplemented by the Appellant at any time prior to the hearing date. a. For any appeal or amendment the county manager, in his sole discretion, may reset the date of the hearing to provide adequate time for review of the amendment or the supplemental information. b. Any amendment or supplementation within ten or fewer days of the scheduled appeal shall automatically require that the hearing date be reset to a date more than ten days in the future. c. Any amendment or supplement, and all exhibits or additional material or information filed therewith, shall be filed in ten copies. (7) Upon the call of the appeal by the presiding officer of the board, appellant shall have 30 minutes to present the appeal. Members of the board shall ask questions as they deem appropriate. At the end of 30 minutes, appellant will cease speaking. The department from which the appeal arose shall have 15 minutes to present its rebuttal. At the end of 15 minutes the department will cease speaking. (8) After both appellant and the department have been heard, the presiding officer shall call for a motion to approve the appeal, to deny the appeal, or to request additional information. In circumstances requiring additional consideration, the board may also move for additional consideration and set a date and time certain to reconvene to consider the matter and render a decision. (9) When sitting for the purpose of considering an appeal, no appeal shall be heard unless at least three members are present at all times during the appeal hearing and decision. All members hearing an appeal must be present for the consideration of the motion on the appeal. Members not present at all times during the appeal may not vote on the motion on the appeal. (10) Any decision upon motion to deny the appeal shall be final. a. No decision to deny an appeal shall be subject to reconsideration by the board except by unanimous vote of the board of commissioners for the sole purpose of preventing manifest injustice. b. In the event a denial is reconsidered, the board may affirm its denial, or structure such solution, as it deems appropriate. Its decision on the matter shall be final and not subject to further review. (Res. No. 2006-30, 6-15-2006) Secs. 2-234—2-259. - Reserved. Sec. 2-508. - Lumpkin County facility naming policy. (a) Purpose. The Lumpkin County Board of Commissioners, recognizing that some public facilities house programs that are dependent, in part, on private funding, encourages those programs to seek the support of friends, corporations, and other private individuals and organizations and does hereby set a policy regarding the naming of facilities and/or rooms. (b) General. Funds raised from private donations may be used in support of the mission and objectives of the program, including funds for the construction of physical facilities, and gifts and grants for other purposes as may be designated by the donor. However, programs are not authorized to commit any county funds for challenge or matching grants or gifts for the construction of facilities or for other purposes. The board of commissioners shall not consider gifts, contributions, or income in determining the allocation of county funds to that program. Private donations shall not be subject to control by the board of commissioners or the county administration except as otherwise provided in board policy or by the Memoranda of Understanding established between a program and the county. A program may not accept gifts of real property without the prior approval of the board of commissioners. A program may otherwise accept gifts, bequests, agreements, or declarations of trust that do not carry obligations to the county that may conflict with state law and that do not impose a financial burden on the program beyond that which can be managed within the program's current budget. If acceptance of the gift or donation would require the program to incur additional cost that cannot be borne within the program's current resources, the program must obtain the approval of the board of commissioners before accepting the gift or donation. Each program must maintain a report of all gifts received by the program and its cooperative organizations through private donations and shall provide an annual report of such gifts to the board of commissioners. Each program is authorized to execute those documents necessary to provide proper fiscal management of those funds accepted under this authorization and to further delegate the authority to execute such documents to the chief financial officer of the program. (c) Introduction. The act of naming a facility is the conferral of not only a high honor but also a conspicuous honor. It publicly exhibits the judgment and standards of the county as well as the board of commissioners and signifies lasting approval of the actions of the honoree. The board of commissioners considers the naming of county real estate and facilities in honor of an individual, family, corporation, foundation, or organization to be one of the highest distinctions it can bestow. Namings may be authorized for a person who has attained prominence generally recognized throughout the county, for outstanding and distinguished accomplishments, for service, or for philanthropic giving. In light of the importance and magnitude of this honor, the following guidelines and process shall apply to all place naming on all property owned or leased by the county under the auspices of a county program. The board of commissioners may establish an (ad hoc or standing) advisory committee to make naming recommendations to the board. The chairman of the advisory committee is the final arbiter of all decisions related to place naming prior to submittal to the board of commissioners for approval in accordance with board policy and procedures. (d) Process for place naming. When the desire for naming is apparent and/or it appears that a contribution (gift) to benefit the program will result in a naming request for a donor or other individual, the county manager must be notified and provided with a profile of the donor or individual being honored, the area of interest along with any proposed stipulations, and information about how the contribution (gift) will be paid. The program seeking donations in exchange for naming rights should ensure that the proposed naming is consistent with the interest of the board of commissioners and is commensurate with the level of prominence, accomplishment, service or philanthropic giving from the person, persons, group, or groups for which the naming will be made. Namings authorized without associated fund raising should be the exception. The board of commissioners will authorize external namings to honor a living person only when that person has been disassociated from employment from local, state, or federal government employment for at least two years prior to seeking the board of commissioner's approval. After review by the county manager, the information will be forwarded to the chairman for his consideration. If approved, the chairman will submit the naming recommendation to the board of commissioners for approval in accordance with board policy and procedures. All naming of facilities, rooms, real estate, facilities, and property owned or leased by the board of commissioners, including facilities constructed, donated, or acquired by affiliated organizations of the county, requires prior authorization by the board of commissioners. In order to assure county and program coordination of naming ceremonies, such events typically are planned through the county manager's office in coordination with the associated program office(s). (e) Signage. All signage to be affixed on or adjacent to any, building, facility, or interior space shall be approved by the board of commissioners (in consultation with the donor). All signage shall be consistent with the county's master plan and design criteria. No signage shall be approved and/ or erected that is in contravention of board of commissioner's policy. All signage must be ADA compliant. (f) Contribution guidelines. When the naming of a facility is based on a monetary contribution, the following guidelines apply: (1) Building: Any person or entity desirous of having a building named shall be able to pursue this end in consideration of a financial contribution so long as the gift amount is at least ten percent of the cost to construct the building or of the estimated value for existing buildings. The gift must be secured at least four months prior to the announcement of the naming and may only occur in accordance with the approval of the board of commissioners. (2) Interior: Any person or entity desirous of having an interior space such as rooms, hallways, etc., named shall be able to pursue this end in consideration of a financial contribution of at least $10,000.00 or $50,00 per square foot whichever is greater. The gift must be secured at least four months prior to the announcement of the naming and may only occur with the approval of the board. At the discretion of the board, there may be reasonable exceptions to the above. The gift, or a signed pledge for the gift, must have been received by the institution before the naming is completed. Deferred or estate gifts are preferred to be irrevocable and defined in writing. Deferred gifts such as bequests, charitable gift annuities, charitable trusts, and life insurance policies may be appropriate for current naming opportunities. Options should be discussed with donors and appropriate assurances secured by the program. Any gift, for a place naming shall be paid over a period of no longer than five years and outlined in writing in a commitment signed by the donor. All other gifts for interiors must be paid in full once approved by the board of commissioners. The gift may be unrestricted or to establish a program endowment or in other ways selected by the donor and is not intended to be restricted to construction and/or facilities related costs. It is the policy of Lumpkin County to forward the formal naming request to the board of commissioners only after at least 20 percent of the gift has been received by the program. Should the request be denied, funds will be returned to the donor. The board of commissioners may also consider in-kind contributions to a project in exchange for naming rights to facilities or rooms. (g) Removal or modification of names. Namings authorized by the board of commissioners shall not be modified without approval of the board. From time to time, situations may occur which would warrant the removal of a name from a building or room in a facility. When the naming authority lies with the board of commissioners, so does the authority and responsibility to remove a name when appropriate. Circumstances may dictate that the parameters under which a place name was bestowed at the program have changed to the extent that consideration must be given to removing the name. These circumstances may include, but are not limited to the following circumstances: The honoree does not follow through on a financial commitment; The honoree fails to maintain the high standards of the county or program or the board of commissioners; or The honoree, person or entity, engages in conduct that constitutes an act of moral turpitude; or for other appropriate reasons. The board of commissioners judges each naming removal situation individually based on the facts. No decision will be made without taking into account all of the facts that are relevant to the decision. The board will endeavor to ensure that the removal of a name is consistent with the interests of county, board of commissioners, and the program. The Lumpkin County Board of Commissioners makes no assurances that a naming will remain beyond the useful life of the facility or in perpetuity. If a facility or feature is substantially changed, a named facility or feature may no longer exist and the program director, in his or her discretion, may seek the board of commissioner's approval to transfer the name to a new facility or feature. (h) Procedures for the removal of names. When it becomes apparent that there may be a reason to consider the removal of a name from a facility, the county manager shall be supplied with the original naming history and all salient circumstances surrounding the removal recommendation. The county manager will present the naming history to the board of commissioners who shall make a determination as to whether a name shall be removed. The removal of a name from a room or other interior space(s) of a facility must be approved by the board of commissioners. (i) Periodic review of naming policy. The county manager shall review this guideline on a regular and recurring schedule in order to assure that it continues to be in compliance with the policies of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 2018-41, Exh. A, 7-24-2018) Secs. 2-509—2-536. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ASSET AND REAL PROPERTY POLICY
Sec. 2-563. - Scope. The purpose of this policy is to clearly define assets and real property, purchased or held, by Lumpkin County Government and the proper procedures for the inventory and disposal of such assets. (Res. No. 2017-86, exh. A, 11-21-2017) Sec. 2-564. - Definitions. (1) Asset. Any item purchased by the county that has an initial, individual cost over $5,000.00 and a useful life of over two years, a serial number, or any item or group of items that is tracked on the county's general ledger as an asset. (2) Real property. Any real estate and improvements on such property. (Res. No. 2017-86, exh. A, 11-21-2017) Sec. 2-565. - General objectives. An asset is defined as any item purchased, or held, by Lumpkin County Government that has an initial, individual cost over $5,000.00 and an estimated useful life in excess of two years. Such assets will be placed on the asset inventory maintained by the office of financial administration. Exceptions to this are vehicles and equipment purchased at State Surplus sales that are required to have a tag or have a useful life over two years or book value over $5,000.00. Such items will be placed on the asset listing even if the item's cost was less than $5,000.00. Donated capital assets are to be recorded at their estimated fair market value at the date of donation. This policy does not apply to "groups" of computers or office furniture purchased that may go over the $5,000.00 limit but individually be less than $5,000.00 unless placing them on the asset listing is beneficial to the county for insurance or depreciation purposes. Assets of the county shall be counted through a physical inventory annually in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 50-16-140 and 50-16-141 and a record of that inventory turned in to the office of financial administration for audit purposes. This policy also applies to all serial numbered items such as firearms, radios, pagers, phones, medical equipment, fire hose, gravel, pipe etc. even though these items may individually be less than the fixed asset threshold such items should be accounted for yearly, and while not maintained on the county asset inventory, each department is required to maintain a listing of these items, perform an annual county inventory, and name the person responsible for each item. Real property that is purchased, or held, by the county shall be reviewed annually for insurance purposes and to make sure the property is still useful to the county. (Res. No. 2017-86, exh. A, 11-21-2017) Sec. 2-566. - Disposal of assets. Assets shall be disposed of once they are no longer of value to the county in accordance with state and local law. Prior to disposal, a listing of all items shall be given to the county manager and division director of finance and special services for review and recommendation for removal from the asset inventory. The list will also be shared with other county departments to determine if an item can be used by another department prior to being placed on a work session agenda. Once the list is finalized, it will be taken before the board of commissioners for final review and a vote taken to dispose of the assets. The disposal of assets shall be handled via a public auction, or if the board of commissioners deems the items to be surplus and of no value, then those items may be disposed via transportation to the Lumpkin County transfer station, with a list of such property dumped returned to finance for inclusion in the annual inventory file, or sold for scrap. If items are sold for scrap, a listing of the items shall accompany the check when it is delivered to finance. The board of commissioners utilizes GovDeals for the disposal of assets. County assets under the $5,000.00 threshold, and not covered by this policy, shall be kept in storage until such time a county auction may be advertised and held. The board may also consider trading vehicles or equipment in with the value applied to the purchase/lease of new vehicles or equipment. Such action shall be spread upon the minutes of the meeting of the board of commissioners. (Res. No. 2017-86, exh. A, 11-21-2017) Sec. 2-567. - Disposition of real property. Disposition of real property owned by the county shall be conducted by public sale in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-9-3, or as otherwise provided by state law. Except as otherwise specifically provided by state law, the county shall not dispose of any real property unless the board of commissioners has declared such real property to be surplus. Real property may be sold by any means deemed most advantageous to the county under the particular circumstances, as determined by the board of commissioners. A sale to a private person shall be for highest net purchase price reasonably obtainable by the county. A sale to another unit of government shall be a fair and reasonable purchase price, which need not be as high as the purchase price obtainable from a private person. (Res. No. 2017-86, exh. A, 11-21-2017) Sec. 2-568. - Sales to county employees. In order to prevent the appearance of impropriety, and in keeping with Lumpkin County's Code of Ethics, county employees and elected officials are prohibited from participating in any sale, auction, or transfer of surplus property to the public to include items disposed on GovDeals or any other method of sale, auction or disposal used by Lumpkin County. Pursuant to the authority granted by O.C.G.A. §§ 15-12-100 and 15-21-100, the clerk of the county court shall assess and collection an additional penalty for all violations of O.C.G.A. §§ 16-13-30, 16-13-30.1 and 16-13-31. No. 2009-61, § 1, 9-11-2009) Sec. 2-642. - Disposition of funds. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 15-21-101, all funds deposited into the special drug abuse treatment and education fund shall be used solely and exclusively for drug abuse treatment and education programs and operations thereof, relating to controlled substances and marijuana. Expenditures from this fund shall be made by the county board or its designee pursuant O.C.G.A. § 15-21-101 after consultation and review of the report from the advisory committee established in section 2-643. (Res. No. 2009-61, § 3, 9-11-2009) Sec. 2-643. - Advisory committee established; purpose; members. The county has established the Lumpkin County Drug Abuse Treatment and Education Fund Advisory Committee to oversee the drug abuse treatment and education fund. The purpose of the committee is to review and approve all requests for funding and expenditures from the drug abuse treatment and education fund as delegated by the county board. The committee shall consist of the following members: (1) One representative appointed by the county board; (2) One representative nominated by the chief judge of the county superior court and appointed by the county board; (3) One representative nominated by the judge of the county juvenile court and appointed by the county board; (4) One representative nominated by the chief judge of the county magistrate court and appointed by the county board; (5) One representative nominated by the judge of the county probate court and appointed by the county board; (6) One representative nominated by the county sheriff and appointed by the county board; (7) One representative nominated by the county district attorney and appointed by the county board; (8) The person serving as the clerk of the superior court; provided, however, that this appointee shall serve as a nonvoting member of the committee; and (9) The person serving as the chief county probation officer; provided, however, that this appointee shall serve as a nonvoting member of the committee. (Res. No. 2009-61, § 2(A)—(G), 9-11-2009) Sec. 2-644. - Financial report of superior court clerk. The superior court clerk shall attend all scheduled advisory committee meetings and give a written report of the detailed financial transfers of the funds identified in section 2-642 into the care and accounting of the clerk and the amount having been paid over to the county board. The period of said report shall be the time period since the last scheduled meeting. The report shall include the report provided at the prior meeting so that there is an overlap of reporting periods. (Res. No. 2009-61, § 2(H), 9-11-2009) Sec. 2-645. - Financial report of chief probation officer. The chief county probation officer shall attend all scheduled meetings and give a written report of the detailed financial transfers of the funds identified in section 2-642 into the care and accounting of the probation department and the amount having been paid over to the clerk of court. The period of said report shall be the time period since the last scheduled meeting; this report shall include the report provided at the prior meeting so that there is an overlap of reporting periods. (Res. No. 2009-61, § 2(I), 9-11-2009) Secs. 2-646—2-650. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - LUMPKIN COUNTY FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT POLICY
Sec. 2-651. - Application. Proper controls over revenue are important to ensure strong financial management practices. This policy applies to and is binding on all collected county-wide revenue, except where state or federal laws may supersede. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-652. - Internal controls. All procedural protocols for cash receipts and accounts receivable shall be subject to proper internal controls established by the Lumpkin County BOC. Finance department personnel shall adhere to the revenue recognition policy and, furthermore, establish a set of standard internal controls that a) shall be properly documented and b) be followed by all staff members to ensure compliance with the policy. Recommended internal controls include: • Segregation of duties for authorization, recording, and custodian functions. Other mitigating procedures may be established if necessary. • Timely deposit of funds. • Timely reconciliation to the general ledger and other supporting accounting ledgers. • Notification of management and internal audit upon any suspicion of fraud. Management shall then notify the appropriate authorities in a timely manner for further investigation. • Periodic review by internal audit of internal control compliance. If management has a suspicion regarding non-compliance with internal control directives, internal audit shall be notified. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-653. - Accounting practices. All receipts and receivables shall be recorded in keeping with current authoritative standards and practices. The Lumpkin County Finance Department uses a modified accrual-based accounting system for recognizing revenue. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-654. - Lumpkin County general fund revenues. Listed below are the county's primary areas of revenue. (1) Taxes. Franchise fees, L.O.S.T sales tax, beer/wine excise tax, insurance premium tax, real/personal property tax, real estate transfer tax. • All tax revenue is recognized monthly. The tax commissioner closes out/prepares tax collections once a month, to which the finance department then receipts (and recognizes) those collections. (2) License and permits. Beer and wine license. • Revenue originating from licensing fees is recognized upon reception. (3) Intergovernmental revenues. Commissioner, sheriff, superior court, victim assistance, public works administration, emergency management, fire department, transportation services, senior center, airport, drug task force, D.F.A.C.S. • Intergovernmental revenue is recognized upon reception. (4) Charges for services. Commissioner, tax assessor, tax commissioner, animal control, detention center, sheriff, clerk of superior court, probate court, Enotah Judicial Circuit, victim assistance, board of elections, roads and bridges, airport, ambulance, park and recreation, fire department, transportation services, senior center, financial administration, data processing, animal shelter, family drug court. • Revenue originating from service charges shall be recognized upon reception. All receivables shall be posted to corresponding accounts at the time of the billing when necessary. (5) Fines and forfeitures. State probation, detention center, clerk of superior court, magistrate court, probate court, victim assistance. • Revenue originating from fines and forfeitures shall be collected (and thus recognized) once a month. (6) Investment income. Commissioner, tax commissioner, clerk of superior court, magistrate court, probate court. • Revenue originating from investment income shall be recognized upon reception. (7) Contributions/donations from private sources. Animal shelter, senior center. • Revenue originating from contributions/donations from private sources shall be recognized upon reception. (8) Miscellaneous revenue. Commissioner, tax commissioner, airport, general government. • Revenue originating from miscellaneous revenue shall be recognized upon reception. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-655. - Billing policy. All receivables shall be established for services provided in advance of payment. Receivables may be due weekly, monthly, quarterly, bi-annually, or annually, depending on vendors, transaction-type, etc. When services are provided by the department prior to the receipt of funds for such services, an on-going accounts receivable record shall be maintained. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-656. - Grant revenue recognition policy. All grant-related revenue entitled and transferred to the Lumpkin County BOC (and, in effect, the finance department) is recognized at the end of the respective grant's reporting period (by quarter, by month, etc.). These reporting periods are based on the multiple and specific conditions of the grant, or by some other authoritative reporting guidelines. In the event that a grant reimbursement is not received by March 31st of the following fiscal year, the reimbursement request will be considered "deferred revenue" for the just-ended fiscal year, and the reimbursement revenue will be recognized when it is received. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-657. - Manual journal entry verification policy. Policy: For all manual journal entries created by any one member of the finance department's staff (excluding the finance director), each journal entry is verified by the finance director before being submitted into the accounting software. For all manual journal entries created by the finance director, the grant/budget specialist verifies each journal entry before submission. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-658. - Lumpkin County inter-fund transfer policy. Interfund transfers are accounting transactions which move fund balance (reserves) from one fund to another. Such transfers are used to 1) move revenues from the fund that the statute or budget requires to collect them to the fund that the statute or budget requires to expend them, and 2) provide unrestricted revenues collected in the general fund (Lumpkin County's primary operating account) to finance various programs accounted for in other funds in accordance with budgetary authorizations. The director of finance as well as the budget/grant analyst possess the designated authority to analyze, prepare, and execute routine/non-routine transfers in the normal course of business. All transfers are allowable under GAAP principles. Generally, any interfund transfer can be categorized into one of two types: (1) Residual equity transfers: nonrecurring or non-routine transfers of equity between funds; such equity may or may not be returned by the recipient fund. (2) Operating transfers: routine transfers for which there is no intent to return any of the transferred funds to the lending fund. With the exception of Capital Road Fund transfers to the SPLOST Fund, all inter-fund transfers that occur within the course of business for Lumpkin County are linked directly to the county's general fund; reserves are either a) transferred from the general fund to a recipient fund or b) transferred to the general fund from another fund. Further, these transfers are readily labeled in one of three ways: transfers (expenses to GF), "Due To" transfers (assets/liabilities of GF), and "Due From" transfers (assets/liabilities of GF). Listed below is the breakdown of Lumpkin County's interfund transfers based on said categorization. Transfers (from GF) to: • E-911 (for portion of expenses not covered by revenue). • Multiple grants (to match grant amounts). • Public defender (county contribution). • Capital projects (construction projects/capital purchases). • Solid waste fund. "Due To" Transfers: • GF to drug rehabilitation fund (for cash held at year end). • GF to law library fund (for cash held at year end). • GF to technology fee fund [probate and magistrate] (for cash held at year end). • SPLOST fund to GF (for expenditures paid). • CDBG fund to GF (for health dept. grant expenses). • Planning fund to GF (for expenditures). • Hotel/motel tax fund to GF (for funds paid to Chamber of Commerce). • Public defender to GF (expenditures). "Due From" Transfers: • Juvenile services fund to GF (for cash held at year end). • Other funds to GF (repayment for inmate fund purchases on credit card). • GF to multiple grants fund (repayment for expenses). (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-659. - Lumpkin County electronic check signature policy. Payroll and accounts payable check distribution: As part of the check distribution process, the Lumpkin County Board of Commissioners (in conjunction with the Lumpkin County Finance Department) uses electronic, template-based signatures for all payroll and accounts payable checks. The authorized signatures, explicitly reserved for and designated to the commission chairman, county manager, finance director, and county clerk, are applied (either individually or in some combination thereof) by default to all aforementioned checks during the printing process. All accounts payable checks require two authorized signatures and are generally supplied with the signatures of the county manager and finance director. Payroll checks are supplied with the chairman's signature, which is all that is required. It should be noted that any of the aforementioned signees have authorization to apply their electronic signatures to any type of check, if necessary; however, the county clerk's signature is never sufficient by itself, and must be accompanied by at least one other authorized signature. Without exception, all respective check register or check proof forms are signed by at least two of the aforementioned authorized signees prior to check disbursement. Lumpkin County also utilizes electronic payments for vendor invoices. The check proof of invoices to be paid requires two authorized signatures, most often the county manager, county clerk, or finance director prior to the file being submitted to the bank for processing. The file must also be approved by the finance director or the budget and grants analyst prior to final processing by the bank. Public defender check distribution: All checks originating and distributed from the public defender fund are also supplied with electronic, template-based signatures; again, only the Chairman, FD, CM, and CC are to be considered authorized signees. Only one authorized signature is needed to validate a PD check, and, generally, the FD's signature is used; however, any of the aforementioned personnel's signatures can be used if the FD is unavailable. Also, only one signature is necessary for a PD check register or check proof, and any one of the four authorized signatures can be used for check/check register verification. Lumpkin County also utilizes electronic payments for vendor invoices. The check proof of invoices to be paid requires one authorized signature, most often the finance director, prior to the file being submitted to the bank for processing. The file must also be approved by the finance director or the budget/grants analyst prior to final processing by the bank. SPLOST check distribution: All checks originating and distributed from the SPLOST fund are also supplied with electronic, template-based signatures; again, only the Chairman, FD, CM, and CC are to be considered as authorized signees. Two authorized signatures are needed to validate a SF check, and, generally, the FD and CM supply the respective checks with their signatures; however, any of the aforementioned personnel's signatures can be used if either the FD or CM is unavailable. Also, two signatures are necessary for a SF check register or check proof, and any one of the four authorized signatures can be used for check/check register verification. Lumpkin County also utilizes electronic payments for vendor invoices. The check proof of invoices to be paid requires one authorized signature, most often the finance director, prior to the file being submitted to the bank for processing. The file must also be approved by the finance director or the budget/grants analyst prior to final processing by the bank. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-660. - Lumpkin County check distribution policy. Brief procedural background: With respect to the operational regulations of the Lumpkin County Finance Department, the accounts payable clerk (APC) is solely authorized to prepare for distribution (or, for "pick-up") any and all checks relating to/affecting the general fund, SPLOST fund, and some drug court related funds. Once a check has been printed by the APC, at least two designated county department heads and/or officials (typically the county manager, finance director, county clerk, or some combination thereof) must 1) verify the elements of the check and 2) add their signature of approval before sending the check to the accounting clerk (AC) for distribution. Once submitted to the AC, the check is sealed in an envelope and held securely for its intended recipient. Policy: After the AC has received the printed and verified check, he/she sends an email notification to its intended recipient. Some checks are produced on a weekly/bi-weekly/monthly basis and may or may not require email notification. Typically, most checks prepared for pick-up are entitled to county employees, but there are some vendors that request pick-up. Unless otherwise noted or excepted, all completed and available checks are to be distributed exclusively to department heads and/or authorized personnel from the company vendor; this measure should substantially diminish the possibility of any kind of confusion in relation to procedure as well as fraudulent incidents, thereby decreasing the county's (and the respective department's/vendor's) overall liability. At the discretion of the FD and AC, some checks can be distributed to county employees who do not manage their respective departments. Lastly, the employee/designated department official/vendor representative picking up the check must sign the accompanying check stub before leaving. This measure will further ensure quality control when said stubs (and all supplemental/remaining documentation relating to the checks) are digitally scanned into DocuScan. The AC keeps all distributable checks in a single folder that is secured in the safe. Again, unless otherwise excepted, department heads are exclusively permitted to pick-up any check respective to their branch. If/when, hypothetically, a check is being requested and the AC is unavailable to distribute, any one finance department employee has authorization to distribute the requested check as long as he/she verifies that the check sufficiently matches the recipient's request and information. Every effort will be made to have all checks available for pick-up every Friday after 2:00 p.m. In the event that a nationally or locally recognized holiday falls on any given Friday, or if an extended holiday (Thanksgiving, Christmas) should take up the majority of a given work week (especially the end of the week), checks will either be a) available for pick-up before the holiday begins or b) available in the upcoming week after the holiday, depending on the given workload for the department. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Sec. 2-661. - Lumpkin County money safe policy. Any department serving under the authority of the Lumpkin County Board of Commissioners that receives, handles, stores, or deposits monies shall be required to use a security safe (with a lock and/or combination, preferably/specifically designed to protect money) for the purposes of housing and securing all said monies. Regardless of the department's protocol procedures for managing monies, all monies receipted in a given business day are to be securely stored in a safe at the close of that business day as a way of ensuring the monies' location. The safe should be stored within the department's designated building in an inconspicuous location, preferably in a lockable closet or underneath a desk. With the exception of authorized employees, this location should be inaccessible to all persons. All doors and rooms surrounding the safe are to be locked at the close of every business day. (Res. No. 2012-69, exh. A, 12-18-2012; Res. No. 2017-64, Exh. A, 9-19-2017) Secs. 2-662—2-672. - Reserved.
