For the purpose of this chapter, the area of Lumpkin County, Georgia, is hereby divided into the character areas listed below and described on the character area Map of Lumpkin County. There are specific development requirements for new development proposed in each character area based upon the land use category of the proposed development as described in section 27-40 et seq. of this chapter. Every lawful land use fits into a land use category, and no otherwise lawful land use is prohibited in any character area. The development requirements are intended to reduce potential conflicts between adjacent land uses by establishing buffers between uses and subjecting certain uses to additional scrutiny and approvals because of the scale of their potential impacts on neighboring and nearby land uses. 2. Character areas: A. Agricultural preservation—Agricultural preservation areas are intended for uses such as conservation, farming, commercial agricultural uses, and very low-density large lot residential development. "Conventional" subdivision development is discouraged in this character area, and maintaining distance between active agricultural uses and new residential uses or other incompatible uses is emphasized. B. Rural places—Rural places is intended for development as rural residential communities connected to the agricultural, economic, environmental, and aesthetic features of the rural and natural landscape through practices such as clustering development at farmsteads and large lot homesteads, crossroad hamlets, or within large lot conservation and master planned developments. C. Residential growth area—Residential growth areas are intended for conventional subdivisions and commercial nodes. Development in this area with be characterized by smaller lot sizes and a greater variety of housing types. D. Industrial— areas are intended for uses that are likely to have negative impacts on neighboring properties or the surrounding area, and particularly those uses that could be potentially dangerous to health, safety, or general welfare if located near residential development. E. Neighborhood village centers—Neighborhood village centers are intended for small-scale commercial uses designed to serve daily local needs of the surrounding area. These uses will generally be retail or service oriented and be located in buildings between 3,000 and 6,000 square feet, but not more than 30,000 square feet. F. Community village centers—Community village centers are intended for commercial, office, and mixed-use developments that serve a region or a larger area than the immediate neighborhood. G. Commerce Corridor — Commerce corridors are intended for commercial, industrial, and other employment uses that do not have significant impacts on the environment or on nearby properties. Examples of these uses include office and business parks, large scale commercial sites, office-warehouse centers, distribution/service facilities, industrial sites, high-technology and research uses, wholesaling companies, and similar businesses. Because of the intensity of use and its potential relationship to residential uses, intensive industrial uses are discouraged in this character area. H. Gateway Corridor—Gateway corridors are intended large-scale commercial, office, technology, and distribution uses along major roadways and transportation corridors. 3. No land shall be developed within a particular character area unless the property is compatible with the requirements outlined within this chapter. 4. For the purposes of this restriction, the term "within" shall mean that character area in which the largest percentage of the relevant parcel lies. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Secs. 27-32—27-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - LAND USE CATEGORIES
Sec. 27-40. - Land use categories defined. Every new structure, building, or land development proposed in Lumpkin County, Georgia shall be classified based on the intended primary use of the structure, building, or parcel into one of the land use categories described below. Every development will have specific development requirements based upon its land use category and on the character area in which the development will be located as described in section 27-30 et seq. of this chapter. Every lawful land use fits into a land use category, and no otherwise lawful land use is prohibited in any character area. The development requirements are intended to reduce potential conflicts between adjacent land uses by establishing buffers between uses and subjecting certain uses to additional scrutiny and approvals because of the scale of their potential impacts on neighboring and nearby land uses. Land use categories referred to in this chapter have the following meanings. 1. Agricultural—Agricultural uses involve the cultivation of crops, dairying, or the raising of livestock. It also includes the conservation of agricultural or natural resources. Agricultural property may include the residence of the owner and other accessory structures. Specific development standards may be applied to the following types of agricultural uses: A. Crop production; B. Greenhouse; C. Plan nursery and floriculture production; D. Pasture or raising of livestock; E. Forestry and logging; F. Commercial fishing, hunting and trapping; and G. Support activities for crop production, animal production, and forestry. 2. Residential—Uses are buildings intended to be occupied or used to house one or more people or families. Specific development standards may be applied to the following types of residential uses: A. Single-family residential; B. Multi-family residential (three or more units); C. Mobile home park (three or more mobile home hook ups); D. Personal care homes (up to 15 under care); E. Rooming houses, boardinghouses, or small lodging facilities (up to 25 rooms); F. Cottage industries; G. Short-term rentals. 3. Commercial—Uses are primarily engaged in the sale of goods; the provision of personal, professional, business, entertainment, or other services; the management of a business enterprise; or the large-scale provision of temporary housing to the traveling public such as a hotel or motel. Specific development standards may be applied to the following types of commercial uses: A. Agricultural commercial—Retail and service establishments primarily oriented towards serving agricultural needs or associated with agricultural activities including value-added agricultural production. Examples include: I. Retail sale of agricultural products, including produce stands; II. Wineries; III. Plant nurseries; IV. Farm equipment rental, sales, service; and V. Veterinary services. B. Neighborhood commercial—Small scale commercial establishments primarily serving the immediate neighborhood. Examples include: I. Small retail shops not significantly engaged in wholesale or mail order business; II. Beauty salon or barber shop, aroma therapy clinic, spa, and other similar personal care services; III. Florist; and IV. Professional services, such as a lawyer, accountant, tax preparer, insurance agent, etc. C. Community commercial—Establishments primarily serving the larger community beyond the immediate neighborhood. Examples include: I. Medical offices and labs; II. Banks, credit unions, and savings institutions; III. Dry cleaning or laundry service; IV. Gasoline service station, convenience store/quick stops; V. Hotels and motels; VI. Medium sized shops, such as drug stores; and VII. Light auto service, such as a tire shop or oil change/service center performing routine maintenance for passenger cars and trucks. D. Intensive commercial—Establishments of a regional character that are likely to attract larger amounts of traffic or intensive traffic from tractor trucks or other heavy equipment. Examples include: I. Hospitals; II. Corporate offices; III. Regional malls; IV. Office, industrial, and business parks; V. Warehousing and distribution; VI. Lumber yards, home supply marts; VII. Tractor truck, utility trailer and RV rental and leasing or sales; VIII. Motion picture theaters; and IX. Heavy auto service, such as body shops, auto painting, and repair for passenger cars and trucks or repairs or service of tractor trucks or other heavy equipment. 4. Industrial—Uses are primarily engaged in the fabrication, manufacture or production of goods, or the storage or distribution of goods and products. Specific development standards may be applied to the following types of industrial uses: A. Light industrial—Light industrial uses are those that wholesaling or warehousing, as well as fabrication, manufacturing, assembly, or processing of goods in such a way that is not likely to have significant impacts on neighboring properties through the production of smoke, odor, dust, noise, vibrations, or any other impacts. I. Light manufacturing, such as medical equipment, signs, sports and athletic goods, computer and electronics; II. Wholesale trade; III. Warehouse and storage; and IV. Transportation, such as taxi and limousine services, general freight trucking and utility substations; V. Communications and utilities. B. Heavy industrial—Intensive industrial land uses are those that that have potential for significant negative impacts on the surrounding area and that could be potentially dangerous to health, safety, or general welfare if located near residential development. This includes any use that emits hazardous or noxious fumes or other discharges or that cause noticeable odors. Examples include: I. Heavy manufacturing; II. Animal slaughtering and processing; III. Rendering or refining of fats and oils; IV. Leather and hide tanning and finishing, except taxidermy; V. Paper manufacturing other than finished stationery products; VI. Petroleum and coal products refining or manufacturing; VII. Mills (textile and paper); VIII. Junk, salvage, and scrap yards; IX. Waste management or disposal services; X. Quarries; XI. Asphalt and cement plants; XII. Processing of sauerkraut, vinegar or yeast; XIII. Wood preservation; XIV. Bulk storage of petroleum, natural gas or other flammable gasses or liquids, other than when it is for direct use or retail sale on site; and XV. Environmentally hazardous uses that require a section 313 permit under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 (commonly referred to as the Clean Water Act), 33 USC 1251 et seq. 5. Public or institutional—Public and institutional uses are those primarily engaged in religious, educational, recreational, or philanthropic activities. Examples include: A. Religious institutions; B. Schools; and C. Cemeteries and mausoleums. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Sec. 27-41. - Principal and accessory uses. 1. The land use category of any proposed development shall be determined by the principal use of the relevant parcel under the proposed development plan. The primary use is the specific, primary purpose for which land or a building is used. 2. Any other use of a parcel or a building that is not an inherent part of the primary use shall be considered an accessory use. An accessory use is incidental to the principal use and would not exist independent of the principal use. A. All structures associated solely with any accessory use shall not exceed 50 percent of the square footage of the principle use structures, except as specifically exempted. This limitation shall not apply to Agricultural uses in the Agricultural Preservation Area. B. If no other setback is specified, all structures associated with any accessory use must be located a minimum of five feet from all property lines where no setback is specified, except as specifically exempted. C. If size or scale of an accessory use relative to the primary use changes such that the accessory use more reasonably functions as a primary use, the planning department shall reclassify the accessory use as the primary use, and it shall be required to meet the appropriate restrictions and development standards for such use or request a variance from such requirements. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Secs. 27-42—27-49. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
Sec. 27-50. - Scope. In order to ensure the compatibility of adjacent land uses, minimize conflicts between neighboring parcels, promote orderly development patterns in Lumpkin County, and generally promote the public health, safety, and welfare, all new development in Lumpkin County will be subject to the follow development standards based on the land use category of the primary use of the property as described in section 27-40 et seq. of this chapter and based on the character area in which the development will be located as described in section 27-30 et seq. of this chapter. No otherwise lawful land use is prohibited in any character area. The development requirements are intended to reduce potential conflicts between adjacent land uses by establishing buffers between uses and subjecting certain uses to additional scrutiny and approvals because of the scale of their potential impacts on neighboring and nearby land uses. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Sec. 27-51. - Agricultural preservation character area. In the agricultural preservation character area, setbacks and other land use requirements are as follows based on the land use category of the new development proposed and the present Land Use Categories of the of the adjacent parcels. In addition to the specific requirements based on a development's land use category, new developments shall meet the following general requirements: 1. General requirements—New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that are not addressed by the development standards below shall comply with the following minimum requirements: A. If the new development is located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 30-foot setback along the right-of-way, and a 20-foot setback off of all other property lines. B. If the new development is not located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 50-foot setback from the right-of-way, and 20-foot setback from all other property lines. 2. Agricultural land use category—New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that fall into the agricultural land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Existing agricultural uses—A new agricultural use in the agricultural preservation character area shall meet the follow minimum requirements. B. The keeping of cattle, hogs, poultry, and other nondomestic animals, other than personal livestock, shall require a minimum lot size of five acres. C. Feedlots and hog parlors shall require a minimum lot size of ten acres. D. Timbering and forestry management practices are allowed as a bona fide agricultural activity, provided it meets the following requirements: I. All timbering and forestry management activities shall comply with the best management practices promoted by the Georgia Forestry Commission. This can be evidenced by a contract between the tree harvesting company and the property owner (the seller) that is consistent with the form and content recommended by the state forestry commission, or by such other evidence deemed acceptable by the planning department. II. Land cleared for timber shall not be developed. No preliminary plat, subdivision plan, site plan for any type of development, or other such project approvals shall be approved if any portion of the property was cleared of trees within three years prior unless such clearing was done as a part of the appropriate land development process described in chapter 26 of this Code. This restriction may be waived by the board of commissioners upon a finding that the tree clearance occurred upon the advice of the county extension agent or the state forestry commission to curtail the spread of infestation of disease. 3. Separation from non-agricultural uses—When a nonagricultural use is to be constructed adjacent to an existing agricultural use, in order to reduce conflicts, potential annoyances, and health hazards, the new development shall provide the following minimum setbacks from the agricultural use: A. Any residential dwelling within a subdivision of three or more lots must be setback 300 feet from the property line or lines it shares with the agricultural use; B. All nonresidential uses, except those uses categorized as agricultural commercial, must be setback 150 feet from the property line; 4. Residential land use category—New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that fall into the residential land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Single-family residential—Single-family residential development in the agricultural preservation character area shall meet the following requirements: I. Minimum lot size: a. Minimum lot size one acre for residential development projects of three parcels or fewer; b. Minimum lot size three acres for residential developments of more than three parcels, unless the developments are mixed-use subdivisions or greenspace subdivisions. II. Greenspace and mixed-use subdivisions shall require a minimum overall residential density of one acre per residential unit. III. All residential uses or subdivisions shall provide a 150-foot vegetative buffer along the side and rear property lines of the development except any property line that is adjacent to an existing subdivision. IV. All lots within a class III, IV, V, VI and VII subdivision as defined in chapter 26 of this Code: a. Must have access from an internal subdivision road; b. No lot in such as subdivision shall have access directly from a county road. c. A ten foot no access strip along the frontage of the property shall be maintained. V. Up to two dwelling units are permitted on a parcel. Guesthouses and accessory apartments are encouraged. B. Multi-family residential (three or more units)—Multi-family residential development in the agricultural preservation character area shall meet the following requirements: I. Minimum lot size of 15 acres; II. Overall maximum density of one unit per acre; and III. Provide a 200-foot vegetative buffer from the side and rear property lines of the development. C. Cottage industries—Cottage industries in the agricultural preservation character area shall be allowed as an accessory use to any residential use provided any structures comply with the relevant setbacks and buffers applicable to the primary use, including all limitations on parking, and the scale of the commercial activity does not exceed that of the primary use. D. Short-term rentals—Short-term rentals in the agricultural preservation character area shall meet the following requirements: I. Structures shall comply with all of the setback requirements of a single-family or multi-family residence as appropriate to the type of structure in question; II. Operators must possess a valid short-term rental host permit; III. Operators must possess a valid occupation tax certificate for each short-term rental location. 5. Commercial land use category—New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that fall into the commercial land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Agricultural commercial—The following agricultural commercial uses shall meet the state requirements: I. Large animal hospitals and veterinary clinics shall locate all structures and other areas actively used at least 200 feet from any structure used for residential purposes. II. Livestock sales or auction facilities, show rings, or other areas used for the display, exhibition, training or sale of livestock: a. Shall maintain a setback of 300 feet from all property lines for any animal quarters; b. Parking areas shall be 25 feet from any residentially used property line. B. Small lodging facilities (up to 25 rooms). I. The minimum lot size shall be two acres; II. Parking areas must be 25 feet from any side and rear lot lines adjacent to a residential use; III. All lighting shall be directed within the property. C. Residential business—New residential businesses in the agricultural preservation character area shall comply with the following requirements: I. All residential business operations must be performed wholly within the principle residence or within an accessory structure that meets the requirements of this character area; II. Safe ingress and egress shall be provided to the property; III. Adequate off-street parking to the side or rear of the property outside of required setbacks, or a minimum of 25 feet from any property line if no setback is required; IV. Any accessory structure used for a residential business must be outside the minimum setbacks; or a minimum of 25 feet from any property line if no setback is required; V. Any materials, equipment, or business vehicles be stored or parked on the premises shall be kept in a well maintained paved or graveled area; VI. All retail establishments shall maintain an opaque buffer and a setback of 25 feet from all property lines; D. Neighborhood commercial—Neighborhood commercial uses are primarily intended for the neighborhood village center character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-55. Any standalone neighborhood commercial uses outside of neighborhood village center character area and in the agricultural preservation character area shall be subject to the following additional requirements: I. All uses must be setback at least 30 feet from the right-of-way; II. A maximum floor area ratio of 0.25 is allowed on a parcel; III. A 20-foot landscaped buffer is required along the side and rear property lines; IV. A five foot wide landscaped strip is required along the front property line; V. Parking lot and loading area landscaping is required for any parking lot accommodating more than five vehicles. E. Community commercial—Community commercial uses are primarily intended for the community village center character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-56. Any standalone community commercial uses outside of community village center and in the agricultural preservation character area shall be subject to the following additional restrictions: I. All uses must be setback at least 30 feet from the right-of-way line; II. Access must be provided from a paved public road; III. A maximum floor area ratio of 0.25 is allowed on a parcel; IV. A 30-foot building setback and a 20-foot wide landscaped buffer are required along the side and rear property lines; V. A ten-foot wide landscaped strip is required along the front property line; VI. Parking lot and loading area landscaping is required for any parking lot accommodating more than five vehicles. F. Intensive commercial—Intensive commercial uses are primarily intended for the commerce corridor character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-57. Any standalone intensive commercial uses outside of Commerce Corridor and in the agricultural preservation character area shall be subject to the following additional restrictions: I. All buildings shall maintain a 100-foot setback from any right-of-way line; II. All access must be from a paved public arterial road; III. A maximum floor area ratio of 0.5 is allowed on a parcel; IV. All development shall have a 100-foot building setback and a 30-foot wide landscaped buffer along rear and side property lines; V. All uses shall contain a 50-foot landscape strip along the front property line. VI. When abutting a residential use, no free standing parking garage may be located closer than the setback required for the primary use, or within 25 feet of any property line if no setback is required. VII. When abutting non-residential uses, no free standing parking garage shall be within 10 feet of any rear or side property line. VIII. Any place of assembly, such as a convention center, gymnasium, stadium, place of worship, etc., shall meet the following requirements: a. Such a facility shall have a minimum lot size of five acres. b. A traffic management and parking plan must be approved by the county engineer. G. The following commercial land uses shall meet the additional requirements described below: I. Outdoor recreational facilities, such as driving ranges, shooting ranges, batting cages, go-cart tracks, etc., shall meet the following requirements: a. A 100-foot buffer shall be required for all components of the use. b. All building structures shall be 200 feet from any non-residentially used or vacant property line, and 500 feet from any residentially used property line. c. A plan for ingress and egress must be approved by the planning department. d. Parking areas must be a minimum of 25 feet from any property line. e. The property shall be enclosed by a security fence of not less than six feet in height along the side and rear property lines. Such fence shall be opaque along property lines adjacent to residential uses. f. Uses that have a high risk of injury on adjacent properties, such as golf driving ranges or batting cages, may require additional screening or fencing at the discretion of the planning department. II. Private ambulance and emergency medical services shall meet the following requirements: a. A SLUA shall be required for this use as a primary or accessory use. b. These uses shall be located on an arterial or collector road, and ingress and egress shall be limited to that arterial or collector road. c. Appropriate traffic signs and signals necessary to advise the motoring public of emergency vehicle access shall be provided by the property owner or business operator. III. Sawmills shall meet the following requirements: a. Temporary or portable sawmills may only be operated to process timber harvested onsite. b. Any sawmill, whether permanent, temporary, or portable shall maintain a setback of 300 feet from any property line adjacent to any residential use. IV. Self-service storage, mini-warehouses shall meet the following requirements: a. No wholesale or retail sales shall be permitted onsite, except for incidental sales of moving supplies. b. As a principal use, a self-storage facility shall not occupy a site larger than 20 acres; as an accessory use, the facility shall not occupy more than five acres. c. Garage bays shall be oriented away from the public right-of-way to the maximum extent possible. d. An opaque buffer shall be provided around the entire property. This buffer may be of opaque fencing at least eight feet high or landscaping that is sufficiently opaque. e. A landscape strip of at least 20 feet in width shall be provided along all street frontages. f. Open storage of recreational vehicles and dry storage of pleasure boats shall be screened from adjacent residential properties. g. Landscaping shall be provided in areas between the property lines and the required fencing. This area shall be designated as a perimeter landscape strip. Landscaping shall be designed, placed, and maintained in such a manner as not to interfere with traffic visibility. V. Truck stops shall comply with the following requirements: a. No building structure shall maintain a 100-foot setback from property line for a residential use, or a school, playground, church, hospital, public library or institution for children or dependents. b. The site shall have a road frontage of at least 120 feet on a major collector or arterial road. c. The site shall have a minimum lot size of two acres. d. All uses other than the dispensing of fuel or truck wash must be contained within a single principal building of not more than 20,000 square feet of gross floor area. Such building may contain convenience shopping space, a restaurant, TV viewing and recreation lounges, restroom faculties, showers and dormitory space. e. No major repairs such as engine overhaul, transmission and differential repairs; body and fender work and other repairs of similar nature shall be performed on site. f. No outside storage of parts or inoperable vehicles is permitted. g. Truck parking area must be at least 300 feet from the property line of any residential used and separated from adjoining residential property by a 200-foot wide buffer. 6. Industrial land use category—New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that fall into the industrial land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Light industrial—Any use that is determined by the planning department to be light industrial within this chapter may be subject to a special land use approval (SLUA) as outlined in section 27-73. In addition, the following shall apply: I. All properties must be a minimum of five acres, unless a larger minimum acreage is stated elsewhere. II. All properties shall maintain a 50-foot setback from all property lines. III. Access must be from a paved county arterial or state road. B. Heavy industrial—Any use that is determined by the planning department to be heavy industrial within this chapter is required to receive a special land use approval (SLUA) as outlined in section 27-73. In addition, the following shall apply: I. All properties must be a minimum of ten acres, unless a larger minimum acreage is stated elsewhere. II. All properties shall maintain a 200-foot setback from all property lines. III. A right-of-way shall be provided for access to the facility. IV. Structures shall maintain a 100-foot setback from the right-of-way provided. V. Access must be from a paved county arterial or state road. VI. All uses shall comply with all relevant state and federal laws, regulations, and permit requirements. VII. Noise abatement and air pollution plans that shall be submitted as part of the required SLUA. C. The following industrial land uses shall meet the additional requirements described below: I. Salvage yards, junk yards, and wrecking yards for vehicles or other scrap materials shall also meet the following requirements: a. The use shall be fully enclosed by an opaque visual buffer, such as chain link with interwoven solid strips, adequate landscaping or wall not less than eight feet in height, which provides visual screening. b. A 20-foot landscaped strip between any property line and the required fencing. A landscaping plan must be submitted as part of the SLUA application. c. A 100-foot setback shall be required from any property line or within 300 feet of any residentially used property line. d. Burning shall be prohibited. e. The site shall be adequately maintained to prevent rodent and vermin infestation. f. Junk vehicles shall not be stacked or layered in an unsafe manner. g. The minimum lot size shall be ten acres. h. The maximum area shall be 25 acres. II. Asphalt plants, temporary batch plants and concrete plants shall also meet the following requirements: a. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. during the months of November, December, January, February, and March. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. during the months of April, May, June, July, August, September and October. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. These restrictions shall not apply to routine maintenance and may be varied with approval from the planning department for special projects, including Department of Transportation projects and large commercial projects. b. Noise abatement and air pollution abatement plans to be approved by the board of commissioners. c. The minimum lot size shall be five acres unless located on the property of an active quarry. d. A 1,000-foot setback shall be required from any residentially used structure, place of worship, or school. e. All mixing shall be done in a sealed process. III. Quarries, mining operations, and other uses involve mining, extraction, crushing, and quarrying of sand, rock, precious metals, and other minerals or elements removed from the earth shall also meet the following requirements: a. All trucks shall use adequate covers to minimize dust emissions and escape of loose gravel. b. A fence consisting of a minimum of three strands of barbed wire shall enclose all portions of the pit area which has a vertical drop (slope equal to or less than 1:1) of more than five feet. Gates shall be provided at all points of vehicular or pedestrian ingress and egress, which shall be locked when not in regular use. c. No bare ground disturbed as part of surface mining operations or any ancillary asphalt and concrete production activities shall be left exposed to view any longer than is reasonably necessary to revegetate. d. No operation is permitted between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., during the months of November, December, January, February and March. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. during the months of April, May, June, July, August, September and October. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. These restrictions shall not apply to routine maintenance and may be varied with approval from the planning department for special projects, including Department of Transportation projects and large commercial projects. e. No direct artificial illumination resulting from the operation shall fall on any land not covered by the application. f. A sound study shall be provided to the county that provides all equivalent sound levels at the boundaries of the property. Sound levels shall not exceed 60 A-weighted decibels (dBA) for projects adjacent to residentially used properties, noise sensitive or public areas; 70 dBA for projects adjacent to commercial and convention areas; 75 dBA for projects adjacent to industrial areas. These measurements will be obtained in accordance with the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), and shall be made with a sound level meter using the A-weighting scale. g. The operator will give noise abatement a high priority through the use of berm construction, tree plantings, recessed plant design, equipment selection, stockpile placement, employee training and operating practices. h. Millisecond-delay blasting shall be used to decrease the vibration levels from blasting. For blasting activities, ground vibration levels shall not exceed at any time at any point within 100 feet of any now existing dwelling unit not on the quarry property 0.50 inches/second peak particle velocity for frequencies below 40 Hz and 2.00 inches/second for frequencies equal to and greater than 40 Hz except that if the measured ground vibration level continuously exceeds 0.50 inches/second particle velocity after a period of one second following the maximum particle velocity, the charges weight per delay shall be reduced so that the particle velocity does not exceed 0.50 inches/second. i. To minimize fugitive dust generated by blasting from drifting off site, all blasting shall be conducted when the wind velocity, as measured by the quarry anemometer located on the scale house at a height of at least 25 feet above ground level, is less than ten miles per hour based on a reading no more than five minutes preceding the blast and on the fact that the highest peak wind velocity as measured by the quarry anemometer over the ten minutes immediately preceding the five minute period just described above was less than 20 miles per hour. Exceptions to this rule may occur if a blast has been loaded and ready to detonate and no decrease in wind velocity has occurred such that further delay could be deemed to increase a potential safety hazard. j. All blasting shall occur between 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m., local time Monday through Fridays, excluding state and federal holidays. Exceptions may be allowed to these time restrictions (but not to the days on which blasting may occur) due to mechanical difficulties or other documented problems. k. All gravel and pit access roads shall be maintained in accordance with state issued air quality permits. l. Prior to development, a ground water study performed by a suitably qualified specialist, will be required and shall state that the quarry development will not substantially alter the aquifers from which surrounding wells are supplied. No excavation shall be allowed to lower the water table of the surrounding inhabited properties to the extent there are wells with potable wells within 1,000 feet of the excavation area without provisions being made, if necessary, to supply said inhabitants with potable water if their existing supply becomes inadequate due to quarry operations. m. Notices shall be posed at regular intervals along the outer limits of the property, which shall warn against trespassing and shall contain a statement pertaining to the use of explosives, if applicable. n. Soil or sand removal or extraction operations shall not be established within 500 feet of any property with a residential use or 200 feet of any other structure. o. Quarries and open pit mines shall not be established within 2,500 feet of a property with a residential use and within 500 feet of any other use. p. Copies of all state permits shall be provided to the planning department. q. Any quarry operation or open pit mine operation (including any ancillary and connected operations such as asphalt and concrete plants and including all contiguous lands owned, leased, or otherwise under control of the quarry or mine operator) which is located in an area designated as intensive industrial and which was validly permitted by the state and had been producing products for sale to the public for at least one year prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall have a vested right to continue operations, shall be grandfathered, shall not be subject to the restrictions contained in this chapter, and shall be entitled to expand its operations on any property contiguous to existing operations which at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived the operator owned, leased, or otherwise controlled. However, any such operations or expanded operations shall be subject to the following: i. All air emissions from the quarry operations and from ancillary operations must be in compliance with applicable state law and with any state issued air permits. ii. All blasting must be performed in compliance with state law; iii. The operations shall not be conducted such as to create a public annoyance or health hazard. iv. Nothing herein shall relieve the operator from the obligation to comply with any contract or agreement with a third party or parties which restricts the operation of the quarry, mine, or ancillary operations thereto. IV. Waste handling or disposal facilities shall meet the following requirements: a. All such facilities shall have an opaque visual buffer shall be constructed around the perimeter of the facility facing the exterior of the property that is either: i. A three foot high landscape earthen berm with a maximum slope of three to one and/or a minimum six-foot high, or ii. A 100 percent opaque, solid wooden fence or masonry wall. b. The facility shall be setback a minimum of 1,000 feet from the property line adjacent to any residential use or 500 feet from the property line of any nonresidential use. c. All activities must take place in a fully enclosed building with no outdoor storage of materials. d. The maximum height of any facility shall not exceed 70 feet above the preexisting grade. e. Composting facilities shall be limited to processing tree stumps, branches, leaves, and grass clippings or similar vegetative materials, and they shall not process animal products, inorganic materials such as bottles, cans, plastics or metals, or similar materials. f. Solid waste landfills shall comply with the following additional requirements: i. The disposal of domestic garbage or trash and the disposal of commercial and industrial waste products shall only be allowed in a sanitary landfill or as otherwise permitted or required by the county health department and in compliance with all applicable state and federal laws. ii. No biomedical or hazardous wastes as defined by federal and state laws shall be disposed or discharged into a landfill site. iii. No waste shall be disposed of within 2,000 feet of any property line or public right-of-way. iv. The location of the solid waste landfill shall be determined by on-site testing or from reliable survey data to indicate soil conditions, water table and subsurface characteristics so as to prevent any drainage or leaching from the sanitary landfill into surface or ground waters. The landfill shall be fully lined and provided with leachate control. v. Supplemental insect and rodent control measures shall be instituted by the person responsible for the operation of the disposal area when considered necessary by the county health department. No animals may be permitted to feed within the disposal area. vi. Dead animals shall be placed into the body of the fill, or the designated areas approved by the county health department upon arrival at the disposal site and covered immediately. vii. A separate vehicle unloading area may be used for the land filling of bulky materials such as tree trunks, tree stumps, oil drums, discarded furniture, appliances and automobiles, which do not contain garbage, putrescible waste or hazardous waste. viii. The County engineer shall approve truck traffic routes and entrances to the facility, which shall include all weather access roads. ix. The landfill site must be accessible without traveling over residential streets. x. All landfills shall have an operator in attendance at all times when the landfill is in use, and all entrances to the landfill shall be barricaded when the facility is closed to the public. xi. Storm sewers shall accommodate any changes in the normal drainage of the property. xii. All solid waste must be compacted. All operators of sanitary landfills must pack and cover all materials with at least six inches of earth daily in such a manner as to prevent fires and meet any and all other requirements of the fire code and state law. xiii. All completed landfills must be covered with at least two feet of earth. xiv. Burning of any kind of refuse is prohibited. xv. Fire control. At least one of the following methods shall be provided to control fires: 1) Access to a sufficient supply of water at the solid waste landfill site. 2) Access to an organized fire department which will provide service upon call. 3) Bury pits. 4) Maintain a stockpile of earth adjacent to the working face of the fill. g. The disposal of any building materials generated while a structure is under construction on a lot or within a development is prohibited. Such waste shall be removed from the property and disposed of in accordance with this Code and state and federal law. V. Utility structures serving more than one lot such as electric transformer stations, telephone exchanges, telephone towers, gas regulator stations, water and wastewater pumping stations, shall meet the following requirements: a. The facility shall be surrounded by a security fence that is at least eight feet high. b. When adjacent to a residential use, the facility shall have a vegetated buffer at least ten feet wide on all sides bordering the residential use. c. The facility may not be used for permanent office space, storage, or for the parking of vehicles. 7. Public and Institutional land use category - A. New developments in the agricultural preservation character area that fall into the public and institutional land use category shall meet the following requirements: I. Cemeteries for human or animal interment are required to meet the following minimum requirements: a. Minimum lot size of ten acres, except for church cemeteries or family plots that shall have at least two acres devoted to such use. b. All graves or burial lots shall be setback not less than 50 feet from any property line or street right-of-way lines. c. Cemeteries or other places of burial recognized by the county tax commissioner as tax exempt (under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-41), and any family plot or other burial ground discovered shall be protected under the requirements of state law O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.. Therefore no plans or permits for any type of development shall be approved that disturbs such a site except in conformance with state law. II. Crematories shall not abut any property line of a residential use. III. Private schools of general and special education are subject to following minimum requirements: a. Minimum lot size of five acres. b. Access shall be provided by a public paved road. c. Temporary mobile classrooms require a special land use approval (SLUA). 8. Development standards for accessory structures. A. Except as provided below, accessory structures shall comply with all applicable setbacks. I. Accessory structures associated with the keeping of livestock shall comply with the setbacks required for such buildings as if they are a primary use in this character area. II. A personal horse stable or barn containing four or fewer stalls on any residential lot needs only to meet the 20-foot setback. III. Private riding stables within an equestrian oriented subdivision for the common use of all residents in the subdivision of five or more stalls shall meet the minimum acreage and the agricultural use setback requirements described in this chapter, though one or more residents within the development may specifically request a variance from these requirements. B. Agricultural operations that are accessory to a primary use, but which are not conducted inside a building shall meet the following requirements: I. Agricultural items normally associated with agricultural must be stored at least 25 feet from any property line. II. The following agricultural operations must be at least 50 feet from any property line adjacent to a residential use: a. Any poultry house, or other structure housing livestock of any type other than kennels and horse stables; b. A horse stable containing more than four stalls, and any corral, pen or horse riding ring; c. Feedlots and hog parlors; and d. Manure and other waste storage containers or pits and agricultural waste impoundment sites. III. A minimum of two acres for the first animal shall be provided, and an additional one acre for each additional animal kept on the property shall be provided, excluding fowl. IV. All animals, excluding fowl, shall be maintained within a fully fenced area. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Sec. 27-52. - Rural places. In the rural places character area, setbacks and other land use requirements are as follows based on the land use category of the new development proposed and the present land use categories of the of the adjacent parcels. In addition to the specific requirements based on a development's land use category, new developments shall meet the following general requirements: 1. General requirements—New developments in the rural places character area that are not addressed by the development standards below shall comply with the following minimum requirements: A. If the new development is located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 30-foot setback along the right-of-way, and a 20-foot setback off of all other property lines. B. If the new development is not located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 50-foot setback from the right-of-way, and 20-foot setback from all other property lines. 2. Agricultural land use category—New developments in the rural places character area that fall into the agricultural land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. The following agricultural structures or uses must be at least 100 feet from any property line adjacent to a residential use: I. Any poultry house, or other structure housing animals or livestock of any type other than horse stables; II. A horse stable containing more than four stalls, and any corral, pen or designated riding ring; III. Feedlots and hog parlors; and IV. Manure and other waste storage containers or pits and agricultural waste impoundment sites. B. Feedlots, hog parlors, and facilities for the keeping, boarding, or breeding of cattle, poultry and other nondomestic animals, shall have a minimum lot size of ten acres. C. All livestock shall be maintained within a fully fenced area, excluding fowl. D. Timbering and forestry management practices are allowed as a bona fide agricultural activity, provided it meets the following requirements: I. All timbering and forestry management activities shall comply with the best management practices promoted by the Georgia Forestry Commission. This can be evidenced by a contract between the tree harvesting company and the property owner (the seller) that is consistent with the form and content recommended by the state forestry commission, or by such other evidence deemed acceptable by the planning department. II. Land cleared for timber shall not be developed. No preliminary plat, subdivision plan, site plan for any type of development, or other such project approvals shall be approved if any portion of the property was cleared of trees within three years prior unless such clearing was done a part of the appropriate land develop process described in chapter 26 of this Code. This restriction may be waived by the board of commissioners upon a finding that the tree clearance occurred upon the advice of the county extension agent or the state forestry commission to curtail the spread of infestation of disease. E. Separation from non-agricultural uses—When a nonagricultural use is to be constructed adjacent to an existing agricultural use, in order to reduce conflicts, potential annoyances, and health hazards, the new development shall provide the following minimum setbacks from the agricultural use: I. Any residential dwelling within a subdivision of three or more lots must be setback 200 feet from the property line adjacent to the agricultural use. II. Any nonagricultural nonresidential use must be setback 100 feet from the property line adjacent to the agricultural use. 3. Residential land use category—New developments in the rural places character area that fall into the residential land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Single-family residential. I. Minimum lot size shall be one acre or greater. II. All subdivisions, except class VII estate subdivisions as defined in chapter 26 and greenspace subdivisions, shall provide a 50-foot vegetative buffer along the side and rear lot lines, unless the lot abuts an existing subdivision. III. All lots within a subdivision of three or more lots: a. All lots must have access from a subdivision road; b. No lot in such as subdivision shall have access directly from a county road; c. A ten foot no access strip along the frontage of the property shall be maintained. IV. Up to two dwelling units are permitted on a parcel. Guesthouses and accessory apartments are encouraged. B. Cottage Industries—Cottage industries in the rural places character area shall be allowed as an accessory use to any residential use provided any structures comply with the relevant setbacks and buffers applicable to the primary use, including all limitations on parking, and the scale of the commercial activity does not exceed that of the primary use. C. Short-term Rentals — Short-term rentals in the rural places character area shall meet the following requirements: I. Structures shall comply with all of the setback requirements of a single-family or multi-family residence as appropriate to the type of structure in question; II. Operators must possess a valid short-term rental host permit; III. Operators must possess a valid occupation tax certificate for each short-term rental location. D. Multi-family residential—Multi-family residential development in the rural places character area shall meet the following requirements: I. Minimum lot size of ten acres; II. Overall maximum density of one unit per acre; III. Provide a 100-foot vegetative buffer from the side and rear property lines of the development; IV. Must be connected to public water and sewer lines or a county-approved community system. 4. Commercial land use category—New developments in the rural places character area that fall into the commercial land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Residential business—New residential businesses in the rural places character area shall comply with the following requirements: I. All residential businesses must be performed wholly within the principle residence or within an accessory structure that meets the requirements of this character area. II. Safe ingress and egress and adequate off-street parking shall be provided to the side or rear of the property outside of required setbacks, or a minimum of 25 feet from any property line if no setbacks are required. III. Any accessory structure used for a residential business must be at least 25 feet from all property lines, and outside the minimum setbacks. IV. Materials, equipment, or business vehicles may be stored or parked on the premises in a paved or graveled area. V. An opaque buffer and a setback of 25 feet from all property lines shall be provided for retail uses. VI. An opaque buffer and a setback of 50 feet from all property lines shall be provided for an intensive commercial uses. B. Agricultural commercial. I. Safe ingress and egress and adequate off-street parking shall be provided for all agricultural commercial uses as described in the parking and loading requirements of chapter 26, article VI of this Code. II. Outdoor storage of inventory, equipment, or other large items shall be considered part of the use, and it must adhere to the relevant setback requirements. III. A farm produce stand, either seasonal or permanent, shall be considered an accessory use to the principal use of the parcel. IV. A setback between the commercial use and any residentially used property shall be 50 feet. C. Neighborhood commercial—Neighborhood commercial uses are primarily intended for the neighborhood village center character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-55. Any standalone neighborhood commercial uses outside of neighborhood village center character area and in the rural place character area shall be subject to the following additional requirements: I. All uses or structures with components that extend below the ground, such as swimming pools, fence posts, etc., must be setback at least 30 feet from the right-of-way II. A maximum floor area ratio of 0.25 is allowed on a parcel. III. A 20-foot landscaped buffer is required along the side and rear property lines. IV. A five-foot wide landscape strip is required along the front property line. V. Parking lot and loading area landscaping is required for any parking lot accommodating more than five vehicles. VI. Access must be provided from a paved public road. VII. Buildings and structures be kept rustic in appearance and designed to fit into their surroundings through the use of building materials such as stone, brick, stained or natural wood siding. The use of vinyl or metal siding is discouraged but acceptable. D. Community commercial—Community commercial uses are primarily intended for the community village center character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-56. Any standalone community commercial uses outside of community village center and in the rural places character area shall be subject to the following additional restrictions: I. All uses must be setback at least 30 feet from the right-of-way line. II. Access must be provided from a paved public road. III. A maximum floor area ratio of 0.25 is allowed on a parcel. IV. A 30-foot building setback and a 20-foot landscaped buffer are required along the side and rear property lines. V. A 10-foot wide landscaped strip is required along the front property line; VI. Parking lot and loading area landscaping is required for any parking lot accommodating more than five vehicles. E. Intensive commercial—Intensive commercial uses are primarily intended for the commerce corridor character area, and thus all such uses shall meet the requirements of that character area as described in section 27-57. Any standalone intensive commercial uses outside of Commerce Corridor and in the rural places character area shall be subject to the following additional restrictions: I. All uses must be a minimum of ten acres. II. All buildings shall be setback of 200 feet from all property lines. III. A 100-foot vegetative buffer shall be provided along the side and rear property lines. IV. Access must be from a paved county arterial or state road. V. When abutting a residential use, no free standing parking garage may be located closer than the setback required for the primary use, or within 25 feet of any property line if no setback is required. VI. When abutting non-residential uses, nor free standing parking garage shall be within ten feet of any rear or side property line. F. The following commercial land uses shall meet the additional requirements described below: I. Any place of assembly, such as a convention center, gymnasium, stadium, place of worship, etc., shall meet the following requirements: a. Such a facility shall have a minimum lot size of five acres. b. A traffic management and parking plan must be approved by the County engineer. II. Outdoor recreational facilities, such as driving ranges, batting cages, go-cart tracks, etc., shall meet the following requirements: a. A 100-foot buffer shall be required for all components of the use. b. All building structures shall be 200 feet from any non-residentially used or vacant property line, and 500 feet from any residentially used property line. c. A plan for ingress and egress must be approved by the planning department. d. Parking areas must be a minimum of 25 feet from any property line. e. The property shall be enclosed by a security fence of not less than six feet in height along the side and rear property lines. Such fence shall be opaque along property lines adjacent to residential uses. i. Uses that have a high risk of injury on adjacent properties, such as golf driving ranges or batting cages, may require additional screening or fencing at the discretion of the planning department. III. Private ambulance and emergency medical services shall meet the following requirements: a. A SLUA shall be required for this use as a primary or accessory use. b. These uses shall be located on an arterial or collector road, and ingress and egress shall be limited to that arterial or collector road. c. Appropriate traffic signs and signals necessary to advise the motoring public of emergency vehicle access shall be provided by the property owner or business operator. IV. Sawmills shall meet the following requirements: a. Temporary or portable sawmills may only be operated to process timber harvested onsite. b. Any sawmill, whether permanent, temporary, or portable shall maintain a setback of 300 feet from any property line adjacent to any residential use. V. Self-service storage, mini-warehouses shall meet the following requirements: a. No wholesale or retail sales shall be permitted onsite, except for incidental sales of moving supplies. b. As a principal use, a self-storage facility shall not occupy a site larger than 20 acres; as an accessory use, the facility shall not occupy more than five acres. c. Garage bays shall be oriented away from the public right-of-way to the maximum extent possible. d. An opaque buffer shall be provided around the entire property. This buffer may be of opaque fencing at least eight feet high or landscaping that is sufficiently opaque. e. A landscape strip of at least 20 feet in width shall be provided along all street frontages. f. Open storage of recreational vehicles and dry storage of pleasure boats shall be screened from adjacent residential properties. g. Landscaping shall be provided in areas between the property lines and the required fencing. This area shall be designated as a perimeter landscape strip. Landscaping shall be designed, placed, and maintained in such a manner as not to interfere with traffic visibility. VI. Truck stops shall comply with the following requirements: a. No building structure shall maintain a 100-foot setback from property line for a residential use, or a school, playground, church, hospital, public library or institution for children or dependents. b. The site shall have a road frontage of at least 120 feet on a major collector or arterial road. c. The site shall have a minimum lot size of two acres. d. All uses other than the dispensing of fuel or truck wash must be contained within a single principal building of not more than 20,000 square feet of gross floor area. Such building may contain convenience shopping space, a restaurant, TV viewing and recreation lounges, restroom faculties, showers and dormitory space. e. No major repairs such as engine overhaul, transmission and differential repairs; body and fender work, and other repairs of similar nature shall be performed on site. f. No outside storage of parts or inoperable vehicles is permitted. g. Truck parking area must be at least 300 feet from the property line of any residential used and separated from adjoining residential property by a 200-foot wide buffer. 5. Industrial land use category—New developments in the rural places character area that fall into the industrial land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Light industrial—Any use that is determined by the planning department to be light industrial within this chapter may be subject to a special land use approval (SLUA) as outlined in section 27-73. In addition, the following shall apply: I. All properties must be a minimum of five acres, unless a larger minimum acreage is stated elsewhere; II. All properties shall maintain a 50-foot setback from all property lines; III. Access must be from a paved county arterial or state road. IV. Light automotive repair. An indoor repair establishment for performing light automotive and small truck repairs such as brakes, oil changes lubrication, transmission belts, hoses, inspections and similar maintenance and repair activities (including tune-ups) is subject to the following restrictions: a. Outside storage of parts or salvaged vehicles shall only be permitted in areas that are visually screened from the right-of-way and from adjacent properties. b. Emissions testing or other auto inspections shall be conducted in a fully enclosed structure. B. Heavy industrial—Any use that is determined by the planning department to be heavy industrial within this chapter is required to receive a special land use approval (SLUA) as outlined in section 27-73. In addition, the following shall apply: I. All properties must be a minimum of 20 acres, unless a larger minimum acreage is stated elsewhere; II. All uses shall maintain a 100-foot setback from the right-of-way unless a greater setback is deemed necessary for public safety and access; III. A setback of 400 feet shall be required from all side and rear property lines. IV. Access must be from a paved county arterial or state road. V. All uses shall comply with all relevant state and federal laws, regulations, and permit requirements. VI. Noise abatement and air pollution plans that shall be submitted as part of the required SLUA. C. The following industrial land uses shall meet the additional requirements described below: I. Salvage yards, junk yards, and wrecking yards for vehicles or other scrap materials shall also meet the following requirements: a. The use shall be fully enclosed by an opaque visual buffer, such as chain link with interwoven solid strips, adequate landscaping or wall not less than eight feet in height, which provides visual screening. b. A 20-foot landscaped strip between any property line and the required fencing. A landscaping plan must be submitted as part of the SLUA application. c. A 100-foot setback shall be required from any property line or within 300 feet of any residentially used property line. d. Burning shall be prohibited. e. The site shall be adequately maintained to prevent rodent and vermin infestation. f. Junk vehicles shall not be stacked or layered in an unsafe manner. g. The minimum lot size shall be ten acres. h. The maximum area shall be 25 acres. II. Asphalt plants, temporary batch plants and concrete plants shall also meet the following requirements: a. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. during the months of November, December, January, February, and March. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. during the months of April, May, June, July, August, September and October. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. These restrictions shall not apply to routine maintenance and may be varied with approval from the planning department for special projects, including Department of Transportation projects and large commercial projects. b. Noise abatement and air pollution abatement plans to be approved by the board of commissioners. c. The minimum lot size shall be five acres unless located on the property of an active quarry. d. A 1,000-foot setback shall be required from any residentially used structure, place of worship, or school. e. All mixing shall be done in a sealed process. III. Quarries, mining operations, and other uses involve mining, extraction, crushing, and quarrying of sand, rock, precious metals, and other minerals or elements removed from the earth shall also meet the following requirements: a. All trucks shall use adequate covers to minimize dust emissions and escape of loose gravel. b. A fence consisting of a minimum of three strands of barbed wire shall enclose all portions of the pit area which has a vertical drop (slope equal to or less than 1:1) of more than five feet. Gates shall be provided at all points of vehicular or pedestrian ingress and egress, which shall be locked when not in regular use. c. No bare ground disturbed as part of surface mining operations or any ancillary asphalt and concrete production activities shall be left exposed to view any longer than is reasonably necessary to revegetate. d. No operation is permitted between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., during the months of November, December, January, February and March. No operation shall be allowed between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. during the months of April, May, June, July, August, September and October. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. These restrictions shall not apply to routine maintenance and may be varied with approval from the planning department for special projects, including Department of Transportation projects and large commercial projects. e. No direct artificial illumination resulting from the operation shall fall on any land not covered by the application. f. A sound study shall be provided to the county that provides all equivalent sound levels at the boundaries of the property. Sound levels shall not exceed 60 dba for projects adjacent to residentially used properties, noise sensitive or public areas; 70 dba for projects adjacent to commercial and convention areas; 75 dba for projects adjacent to industrial areas. These measurements will be obtained in accordance with the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), and shall be made with a sound level meter using the (a-) weighting scale. g. The operator will give noise abatement a high priority through the use of berm construction, tree plantings, recessed plant design, equipment selection, stockpile placement, employee training and operating practices. h. Millisecond-delay blasting shall be used to decrease the vibration levels from blasting. For blasting activities, ground vibration levels shall not exceed at any time at any point within 100 feet of any now existing dwelling unit not on the quarry property 0.50 inches/second peak particle velocity for frequencies below 40 Hz and 2.00 inches/second for frequencies equal to and greater than 40 Hz except that if the measured ground vibration level continuously exceeds 0.50 inches/second particle velocity after a period of one second following the maximum particle velocity, the charges weight per delay shall be reduced so that the particle velocity does not exceed 0.50 inches/second. i. To minimize fugitive dust generated by blasting from drifting off site, all blasting shall be conducted when the wind velocity, as measured by the quarry anemometer located on the scale house at a height of at least 25 feet above ground level, is less than ten miles per hour based on a reading no more than five minutes preceding the blast and on the fact that the highest peak wind velocity as measured by the quarry anemometer over the ten minutes immediately preceding the five minute period just described above was less than 20 miles per hour. Exceptions to this rule may occur if a blast has been loaded and ready to detonate and no decrease in wind velocity has occurred such that further delay could be deemed to increase a potential safety hazard. j. All blasting shall occur between 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m., local time Monday through Fridays, excluding state and federal holidays. Exceptions may be allowed to these time restrictions (but not to the days on which blasting may occur) due to mechanical difficulties or other documented problems. k. All gravel and pit access roads shall be maintained in accordance with state issued air quality permits. l. Prior to development, a ground water study performed by a suitably qualified specialist, will be required and shall state that the quarry development will not substantially alter the aquifers from which surrounding wells are supplied. No excavation shall be allowed to lower the water table of the surrounding inhabited properties to the extent there are wells with potable wells within 1,000 feet of the excavation area without provisions being made, if necessary, to supply said inhabitants with potable water if their existing supply becomes inadequate due to quarry operations. m. Notices shall be posed at regular intervals along the outer limits of the property, which shall warn against trespassing and shall contain a statement pertaining to the use of explosives, if applicable. n. Soil or sand removal or extraction operations shall not be established within 500 feet of any property with a residential use or 200 feet of any other structure. o. Quarries and open pit mines shall not be established within 2,500 feet of a property with a residential use and within 500 feet of any other use. p. A copy of all state permits shall be provided to the planning department. q. Any quarry operation or open pit mine operation (including any ancillary and connected operations such as asphalt and concrete plants and including all contiguous lands owned, leased, or otherwise under control of the quarry or mine operator) which is located in an area designated as intensive industrial and which was validly permitted by the state and had been producing products for sale to the public for at least one year prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall have a vested right to continue operations, shall be grandfathered, shall not be subject to the restrictions contained in this chapter, and shall be entitled to expand its operations on any property contiguous to existing operations which at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived the operator owned, leased, or otherwise controlled. However, any such operations or expanded operations shall be subject to the following: r. All air emissions from the quarry operations and from ancillary operations must be in compliance with applicable state law and with any state issued air permits. s. All blasting must be performed in compliance with state law; t. The operations shall not be conducted such as to create a public annoyance or health hazard. u. Nothing herein shall relieve the operator from the obligation to comply with any contract or agreement with a third party or parties which restricts the operation of the quarry, mine, or ancillary operations thereto. IV. Utility structures serving more than one lot such as electric transformer stations, telephone exchanges, telephone towers, gas regulator stations, water and wastewater pumping stations, shall meet the following requirements: a. The facility shall be surrounded by a security fence that is at least eight feet high. b. When adjacent to a residential use, the facility shall have a vegetated buffer at least ten feet wide on all sides bordering the residential use. c. The facility may not be used for permanent office space, storage, or for the parking of vehicles. 6. Public and institutional land use category. A. New developments in the rural places character area that fall into the public and institutional land use category shall meet the following requirements: B. Cemeteries for human or animal interment are required to meet the following minimum requirements: I. Minimum lot size of ten acres, except for church cemeteries or family plots that shall have at least two acres devoted to such use. II. All graves or burial lots shall be setback not less than 50 feet from any property line or street right-of-way lines. III. Cemeteries or other places of burial recognized by the county tax commissioner as tax exempt (under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-41), and any family plot or other burial ground discovered shall be protected under the requirements of state law O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.. Therefore no plans or permits for any type of development shall be approved that disturbs such a site except in conformance with state law. C. Crematories shall not abut any property line of a residential use. D. Private schools of general and special education are subject to following minimum requirements: I. Minimum lot size of five acres. II. Access shall be provided by a public paved road. III. Temporary mobile classrooms require a special land use approval (SLUA). 7. Development standards for accessory structures. A. A maximum height for accessory structures shall be two stories or 35 feet. B. Except as provided below, accessory structures shall comply with all applicable setbacks. I. A personal horse stable or barn that does not contain more than four stalls may be provided on any residential lot. II. A minimum of three acres for the first animal shall be provided, and an additional 1.5 acre for each additional animal kept on the property, excluding fowl. III. A minimum of 1.5 acre for each 20 fowl shall be provided. IV. All animals shall be maintained within a fully fenced area, excluding fowl. V. Private riding stables within an equestrian oriented subdivision for the common use of all residents in the subdivision of five or more stalls shall meet the minimum acreage and distancing requirements as described in this chapter. A resident within the development may specifically request that distancing requirements be waived. (Res. No. 2019-05, 1-22-2019) Sec. 27-53. - Residential growth. In the residential growth character area, setbacks and other land use requirements are as follows based on the land use category of the new development proposed and the present land use categories of the of the adjacent parcels. In addition to the specific requirements based on a development's land use category, new developments shall meet the following general requirements: 1. General requirements—New developments in the residential growth character area that are not addressed by the development standards below shall comply with the following minimum requirements: A. If the new development is located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 30-foot setback along the right-of-way, and a 20-foot setback off of all other property lines. B. If the new development is not located in a subdivision, the use shall maintain a 50-foot setback from the right-of-way, and 20-foot setback from all other property lines. 2. Agricultural land use category—New developments in the residential growth character area that fall into the agricultural land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. The following uses must be at least 300 feet from any property line adjacent to any property in the residential land use category: I. Any poultry house or other structure housing livestock of any type other than kennels and horse stables. II. A horse stable containing more than four stalls, corral, pen or horse ring. III. Manure and other waste storage containers or pits or any type of agricultural waste impoundment sites. B. All livestock shall be maintained within a fully fenced area. C. Feedlots and hog parlors shall meet the following requirements: I. Such uses shall require a SLUA due to the residential nature of this character area. II. Feedlots and hog parlors must be at least 300 feet from any property line adjacent to any property in the residential land use category. D. Keeping of cattle, poultry and other nondomestic animals, other than in a feedlot or hog parlor, shall require a minimum lot size of 20 acres. E. A kennel, veterinary hospital or clinic shall require a minimum lot size of five acres and the number of animals maintained as breeding stock shall not exceed four. F. Timbering and forestry management practices are allowed as a bona fide agricultural activity, provided it meets the following requirements: I. All timbering and forestry management activities shall comply with the best management practices promoted by the Georgia Forestry Commission. This can be evidenced by a contract between the tree harvesting company and the property owner (the seller) that is consistent with the form and content recommended by the state forestry commission, or by such other evidence deemed acceptable by the planning department. II. Land cleared for timber shall not be developed. No preliminary plat, subdivision plan, site plan for any type of development, or other such project approvals shall be approved if any portion of the property was cleared of trees within three years prior unless such clearing was done a part of the appropriate land development process described in chapter 26 of this Code. This restriction may be waived by the board of commissioners upon a finding that the tree clearance occurred upon the advice of the county extension agent or the state forestry commission to curtail the spread of infestation of disease. G. Separation from non-agricultural uses—When a nonagricultural use is to be constructed adjacent to an existing agricultural use, in order to reduce conflicts, potential annoyances, and health hazards, the new development shall provide the following minimum setbacks from the agricultural use: I. Any residential dwelling must be setback 100 feet from the property line adjacent to the agricultural use. II. Any nonagricultural nonresidential use must be setback 50 feet from the property line adjacent to the agricultural use. 3. Residential land use category—New developments in the residential growth character area that fall into the residential land use category shall meet the following requirements: A. Single-family residential—All types of conventional subdivisions as outlined within the county land development and land use provisions as provided in this chapter. I.
